dbs:foil.title: What this presentation covers
dbs:foil.para: Capabilities of my station, given my particular combination of hardware and software.
The personal experiences of one radio amateur. Your mileage may vary!

dbs:foil.title: What this presentation does not cover
dbs:foil.para: How to partition your disks, back up your data, install an operating system, or perform basic administration tasks.
Copious detail on how to use the individual programs highlighted here. Some programs will have more detail than others.

warning.para: Back up your data before doing anything drastic to your computer!
Connect to a dummy load before experimenting with anything that could transmit!
RF can cause weird things to happen on computers. Be prepared to add RF chokes to power and data cables.

dbs:foil.title: Early experiences
dbs:foil.para: &ibm; &pc;, &commodore; VIC-20 and C-64, &apple; ][
&atari; 2600, &nintendo; Entertainment System
Electronics kits. Connect jumper wires to components to create semi-useful gadgets!
Isaac Asimov (Foundation, Robots), Franklin W. Dixon (Hardy Boys), J.R.R. Tolkien (Something with hobbits and rings)

dbs:foil.title: Papa Maurice
dbs:foil.para: Worked on aircraft and their engines at Edwards AFB in the high desert of Southern California.
Took me and my brother to Mojave Airport many times to look at airplanes.
Designed, planned, and built many of the additions to his house!
"Mechanically inclined" would be an understatement.
Voyager Aircraft and Space Shuttle Challenger made quite an impression on a young mind!

dbs:foil.title: Granddad Stephen
dbs:foil.para: U.S. Army intelligence.
Initially licensed in Massachusetts as W1BAN in 1930.
Changed to W6SFI after moving to California in 1941.
Quarter Century Wireless Association #11,768.
Worked CW, SSB, local repeaters, SSTV.
Actively encouraged my interest in computers.

dbs:foil.title: High School: Moody Nerd in Denial
dbs:foil.para: Slurped up all the available mathematics courses, through calculus.
Chemistry, because it had more math than biology.
Skipped mechanical physics, went straight for electricity & magnetism.
Latin, with its myriad conjugations, declensions, etc. Not applicable to everyday life, seriously uncool...what's not to love?
A little bit of computer programming.
Just enough history, English, art, etc. to meet requirements.

dbs:foil.title: College years: UC Berkeley
dbs:foil.para: An academically humbling experience, relative to high school!
Couldn't handle a mathematics major, settled for computer science instead.
When working on a computer science degree at UC Berkeley, difficult to avoid the deep computing history there.
Joined a student computing club that was most likely to get in trouble with the campus system and network administrators :-)
Learned a few computer langauges, actively pursued a &windows;-free existence with heavy use of open-source software.
So much to learn, so little time, so little parental funding...somehow graduated on time.

dbs:foil.title: Professional Career
dbs:foil.para: Always trying to be versatile and curious, favoring &unix;-like computing environments and open-source tools.
Still haven't figured out how to balance in-house workers' time versus paying a vendor for a product.
Combined with my curiosity about things...I'm not management material yet :-)

dbs:foil.title: My journey to amateur radio
dbs:foil.para: Still curious about &stem; topics. (Just look at my "Watch Later" playlist on YouTube...)
Numbers stations on shortwave radio! What's the deal with that?
Can I build that? (Physically, not in software)
How does that work? What's underneath it?
How little do I need to maximize my capabilities?
Is there a book on it at my local public library?

dbs:foil.title: NooElec SDR and upconverter
dbs:foil.para: Receives 24-1766 MHz with external antenna.
Additional software required to demodulate what you receive.
With transverter shift of -125 MHz, can also receive 0-24 MHz!

dbs:foil.title: ICOM IC-7200 transceiver
dbs:foil.para: Covers 0-54 MHz.
&cw;, &ssb;, &am;, &rtty;, digital modes, but no &fm;.
Up to 100 watts output power.

dbs:foil.title: Yaesu FTM-3100 transceiver
dbs:foil.para: Covers 136-174 MHz.
Analog &fm; only!
5 to 65 watts output power.

dbs:foil.title: MFJ-949E transmatch
dbs:foil.para: Totally manual and passive.
2 antennas, 12-position inductor, 2 variable capacitors.
Connectors for coax or balanced line.
Can handle up to 300 watts.
Integrated dummy load and &swr; meter; handy for testing!

dbs:foil.title: RigBlaster nomic
dbs:foil.para: Enables digital modes for older or less featureful transceivers.
While testing, make sure to have a dummy load handy!

dbs:foil.title: SODIAL LD-C103 &usb; &cw; interface
dbs:foil.para: Turns a &usb; port into a software-controlled straight key.
Earn dirty looks from hard-core mechanical key enthusiasts!
Set up your rig to expect a straight key, or disable its internal keyer.

dbs:foil.title: Antennas
dbs:foil.para: Alpha-Delta DX-EE multi-band dipole, covers 40-6 meters.
Copper pipe J-pole, covers 2 meters & 70 centimeters.
End-fed 120-foot long wire, covers 160-60 meters.

dbs:foil.title: Computer specifications
dbs:foil.para: 16 &gb; memory. Probably too much, but software only grows over time...
250 &gb; solid-state disk -- definitely too much, but far faster and quieter than spinning platters of rust!
&intel; Core i5, 2.7 GHz, 4 cores -- probably overkill.
Mini-&itx; form factor motherboard and case -- nice and compact!

dbs:foil.title: ubuntu.foil
Ubuntu Linux
dbs:foil.para: Probably the best combination of user-friendly desktop environment plus all the low-level command-line power tools you could want, with a very low price (your time and effort).
Can take advantage of packaging work done by &debian; -- very important for easy acquisition of ham-related software!
Not actually my preferred operating system (&freebsd;) but more popular and thus better supported. Besides, much open-source software is written for &linux; first.
Download an image from the web site, burn it to &usb; stick or &dvd;, and install.

dbs:foil.title: Setting up the operating system
dbs:foil.para: Most application software can be installed from the &ubuntu; Software application.

listitem.para: Web browser: &chromium; or &firefox;
Mail reader: &evolution; or &thunderbird;
Office suite: &libreoffice;

dbs:foil.title: A word about keyboards
dbs:foil.para: &linux; and &unix;-like operating systems have a long history of providing very focused tools that are very good at what they do -- and nothing else -- and encouraging users to combine those tools to accomplish their tasks.
This generally means that:

listitem.para: You must get friendly with your keyboard.
You must find where the terminal program is.
Even if you have a nice graphical environment, you must get comfortable entering commands at a shell.
You must learn a text editor: &vim; (descendant of the venerable &vi;), &emacs; or &nano;

note.para: You need not publicly take sides in the long-running &emacs; versus &vi; holy war. :-)

dbs:foil.title: Adding additional software repositories
dbs:foil.para: By adding additional software repositories beyond those that come with &ubuntu;, you gain access to ham-related software and you also make it easier to install updates later!
After you find an interesting repository, you can add it with the instructions on that page. If you're the command-line type, you can (e.g.):
dbs:foil.screen: &ps1; sudo apt-add-repository ppa:ubuntu-hams-updates/ppa &ps1; sudo apt-get update
dbs:foil.para: Since you are a radio amateur, you may want to look into these repositories:

listitem.para: &wsjtx; for weak signal work: ppa:ki7mt/wsjtx
&cqrlog; for logging: ppa:ok2cqr/ppa
&fldigi; for digital modes: ppa:kamalmostafa/fldigi
A lot of other software related to amateur radio: ppa:ubuntu-hams-updates/ppa

dbs:foilgroup.dbs:foil:
Serial ports
Serial ports are commonly used by amateur radio hardware to allow computer control.
Lots of devices have &usb;-to-serial hardware built in.
Most serial ports have boring, indistinct names that are allocated as the devices are plugged in and/or powered on.
&ls.ttyusb;
However your operating system may also provide more descriptive names that are not based on when the device was plugged in.
&ls.serial.by-id;

Serial ports &ls.ttyusb; &ls.serial.by-id;
Remember where to find these! You may need to put them in configuration files later.
Also add yourself to group dialout so that you can access those serial ports as yourself, without being the root superuser!
If you attach two devices that use the same very popular chip set, they may be indistinguishable by name. You will have to resort to number instead.
The chip set from &prolific; appears in many &usb;-to-serial cables as well as some &usb; &gps; devices...and probably a lot of other stuff too!

dbs:foil.title: Working with sound cards
dbs:foil.para: In addition to the built-in sound card on the motherboard, you can add as many &usb; sound cards as you want.
Newer amateur radio hardware that emits sound output or accepts sound input can appear as a sound card when it is attached.

Addressing individual sound devices is trickier than with serial ports. The operating system does some magic behind the scenes to allow multiple programs to access them, and they have funny addresses.
I have 3 sound cards on the computer right now:

listitem.para: The built-in sound card on the motherboard
Headset with microphone, attached via &usb;
&icom; IC-7200 attached via &usb;

dbs:foil.para: To find the addresses of individual sound devices, I find myself using:

listitem.para: For playback only: aplay -l
For recording only: arecord -l
For an exhaustive list: aplay -L

dbs:foil.title: Scanner and pandapter: hardware
dbs:foil.para: Many programs can read from an attached &sdr; dongle.

warning.para: If you run a transmitting rig near this hardware, put ferrite chokes on the &usb; cables!

dbs:foil.title: Scanner and pandapter: software
dbs:foil.para: The program &gqrx.link; will read from an attached &sdr; dongle.
It can detect the presence of any RF signal, and can demodulate analog &am;, &fm;, &cw;, and &ssb; in software.
It can also record audio or raw I/Q to a file, and make audio available for other programs to consume, possibly over the network!

dbs:foil.title: Computer control of a rig with &hamlib;
dbs:foil.para: The nice folks at &hamlib.link; wrote a library that gives a common interface to many (hundreds of) rigs.
Many popular programs that control rigs are built on &hamlib;!

dbs:foilgroup.dbs:foil:
Setting up &hamlib;
For most applications, all you need to find out are:
A &hamlib; model id number
The name of the serial port device
&ps1; rigctl -l | head -5 Rig # Mfg Model Version Status 1 Hamlib Dummy 0.5 Beta 2 Hamlib NET rigctl 0.3 Beta 101 Yaesu FT-847 0.5 Beta 103 Yaesu FT-1000D 0.0.6 Alpha &ps1; rigctl -l | grep IC-7200 361 Icom IC-7200 0.7 Beta
We already found the serial port earlier!
&ls.ttyusb;

dbs:foil.title: Many programs sharing one rig
dbs:foil.para: But what if you want multiple programs on one machine to use your rig?
Or, even crazier yet, let a program elsewhere on the network use your rig?
&hamlib; to the rescue again!
Set up the &hamlib; program &rigctld; with the rig ID number and the serial port device.
Set up the remote program with rig ID number 2 (NET rigctl) and direct it to the host and port where &rigctld; is running.

dbs:foil.title: Logging with &cqrlog;
dbs:foil.para: If &cqrlog; has a work-alike in the &windows; space, it is &n1mm; or &hrd;.
&rigctld;, &cwdaemon;, &rbn.link;, &dx; cluster, &xplanet;, grayline map, &hamqth.link;, &qrz.link;, &lotw.link;, &eqsl.link;, &clublog.link;...too many capabilities to count!

dbs:foil.title: &cqrlog; features
dbs:foil.para: The preferences window has multiple tabs. Yes, it is a deep rabbit hole.

dbs:foil.title: &cqrlog; features of note
dbs:foil.para: Launch &rigctld; on startup, and use it for rig control and logging assistance.
Slurp over logs from &fldigi; or &wsjtx;. (But not simultaneously.)
&cw; macros and a contest entry window, with support for serial numbers!
From the online help:

blockquote.para: This is NOT a contest logging add-on!!! It is meant to be a tool for "Sunday contesters working in Tourist Class". Do not expect wonders!

dbs:foil.title: Exporting logs from &cqrlog;
dbs:foil.para: If you use &lotw; and have &tqsl; installed, &cqrlog; can make the signing and uploading process easier.
And then afterwards, you can find the individual &adif; file and upload it to your favorite logbook site (e.g. &qrz.link;, &eqsl.link;, &clublog.link;, &qrzcq.link;).

dbs:foil.title: &qtel; for EchoLink
dbs:foil.para: Not much to say. Enter your credentials, set up the audio devices, and go!

dbs:foil.title: Weak signal modes with &wsjtx;
dbs:foil.para: In &cqrlog;, first set &remote.wsjtx.guimenuitem; then launch &wsjtx;.
&wsjtx; doesn't like sharing the rig; make sure it's the only process using it!
After you're done with &wsjtx;, remember to disable &remote.wsjtx.guimenuitem;.

dbs:foil.title: Digital modes and contests with &fldigi;
dbs:foil.para: &fldigi; can use its own &rigcat; system, but &hamlib; without &rigctld; seems to work better in my case.
Still have to manually set the rig to take modulation from computer. Can be annoying on band changes! Perhaps newer &hamlib; solves this?
Set &cqrlog; to &remote.fldigi.guimenuitem; before launching &fldigi;, then communication between the two should work fine.
Remember to disable &remote.fldigi.guimenuitem; after you're done with &fldigi;.

dbs:foil.title: Packet radio with &direwolf;
dbs:foil.para: &direwolf; is a software &tnc; that can interface with a sound card and a serial port.
dbs:foil.programlisting: # see /usr/share/doc/direwolf/examples/direwolf.conf.gz ADEVICE sysdefault:CARD=PCH ACHANNELS 1 CHANNEL 0 MYCALL W6SFI-1 MODEM 1200 PTT /dev/ttyUSB0 RTS DTR AGWPORT 8000 KISSPORT 8001
dbs:foil.para: You can run &direwolf; silently in the background, or watch it scroll in a terminal.

dbs:foil.title: &aprs; with &xastir;
dbs:foil.para: &direwolf; is much better when you combine it with other programs that actually know what to do with packets, like &xastir;.
&xastir; gets even better when you attach it to a &gps; dongle and a weather station.

For those who don't like to buy purpose-built tracker hardware, there are many guides on the internet about how to combine a Raspberry Pi, &direwolf;, &xastir;, and a &gps; dongle into a portable &aprs; solution.

dbs:foil.title: &direwolf; for &ax25;
dbs:foil.para: With a slightly different configuration, &direwolf; can be convinced to be a &kiss; &tnc; for generic &ax25; operation.
dbs:foil.programlisting: # see /usr/share/doc/direwolf/examples/direwolf.conf.gz ADEVICE sysdefault:CARD=PCH ACHANNELS 1 CHANNEL 0 MYCALL W6SFI-2 MODEM 1200 FIX_BITS 1 AX25 PTT /dev/ttyUSB0 RTS DTR AGWPORT 8000 KISSPORT 8001

dbs:foil.title: Packet radio with &linpac;
dbs:foil.para: &linpac; can spew packets out into the ether, or connect to a packet &bbs;.

dbs:foil.title: Computer-generated &cw; with &cwdaemon;
dbs:foil.para: Are you better at keyboards than straight keys or paddles? This may be for you!
Configuring your particular keyer device is beyond the scope of this presentation; mine required none.
Start it up!
dbs:foil.screen: &ps1; sudo service cwdaemon start &ps1; nc -u localhost 6789 +- CQ DE W6SFI PSE K ^C
dbs:foil.para: Did it work?

dbs:foil.title: Contesting with &tlf;
dbs:foil.para: &tlf.link; is a console-based contest logger. Run it in an 80x25 terminal with a huge font.
&tlf; is operated entirely by keyboard, and configured entirely by text files.
Best to configure things in advance, and read the documentation thoroughly.
Most of the features you would expect in dedicated contest software:

listitem.para: Configurable preset CW messages available at single keystrokes
Bind voice keyer messages to keys for SSB contests
Smart Enter key often does what you want.
Band map, DX cluster, Super Check Partial, rig control, score window, log review, duplicate detection...
A few contests built in, plus facilities for handling unknown contests or just general non-contest logging.
Contest simulator! (Not a pileup simulator.) You may want to switch to the dummy load for this.

dbs:foil.title: Configuring &tlf;: main configuration file
dbs:foil.programlisting: CALL=W6SFI CWSPEED=20 CLUSTER BANDMAP SCOREWINDOW CHECKWINDOW PARTIALS RIGMODEL=361 RIGSPEED=9600 RIGPORT=/dev/serial/by-id/usb-Silicon_Labs_CP2102_USB_to_UART_Bridge_Controller_IC-7200_0205281-if00-port0 RADIO_CONTROL CONTEST=arrldx NETKEYER NO_BANDSWITCH_ARROWKEYS

dbs:foil.title: Configuring &tlf;: the rules file
dbs:foil.programlisting: CONTEST=arrldx LOGFILE=arrldx.log CONTEST_MODE CABRILLO=UNIVERSAL THREE_POINTS MULT_LIST=arrl10m_mults MY_COUNTRY_POINTS=0 COUNTRY_MULT F1=+- CQ % TEST F2=+- % F3=+- @ +++5NN--- CA F4=+- TU F5=+- @ F6=+- % F7=+- @ SRI QSO B4 GL F8=+- AGN F9=+- ? F10=+- QRZ? F11=+- PSE K F12=+- CQ % TEST CQ_TU_MSG=+- TU % S&P_TU_MSG=+- TU +++5NN--- CA ALT_1=+- CA CA CA ALT_2=+- PWR? PWR? S&P_CALL_MSG=+- %

dbs:foil.title: &tlf; after a contest
dbs:foil.para: Export your data to Cabrillo format with :WRI and send in your entry.
Export your contacts to &adif; format with :ADI and load them back into &cqrlog;!

dbs:foil.title: &ssb; contesting with &tlf;
dbs:foil.para: Need to prepare a bunch of .wav files that &tlf;'s voice keyer can play automatically.
Also need to write a script that uses a recent-enough version of &hamlib; to put the rig into all the right modes, plays the .wav to it, and then puts the rig back!
I know this can be done, because &wsjtx; knows all the right buttons to push, and it uses &hamlib;.

dbs:foil.title: Slow-Scan TeleVision
dbs:foil.para: I've spent too much time wrestling with bugs in the &qsstv; image editor to complete an actual &sstv; &qso;.
Still, I have managed to at least decode a few transmissions. Some are even intelligible!

dbs:foil.title: &freedv;: digital voice over &hf;
dbs:foil.para: &freedv.link; is a digital voice application, primarily for &hf; use.
&freedv; uses open-source non-proprietary codecs.
&qso.freedv.link; can help you find other operators using &freedv;.

dbs:foil.title: &r;: Internet Protocol over packet radio
dbs:foil.para: Forward-thinking radio amateurs allocated an entire class A block 44.0.0.0/8 for internet use!
It is not meant to replace regular internet access. It is mostly meant for research, experimentation, and advancing the state of the art.
&ampr.link; manages subnet allocations and provides pointers to other information.

dbs:foil.title: &winlink; and &pat;
dbs:foil.para: Who says &winlink; is limited to &windows; users?
&pat; is a cross-platform &winlink; client that should run on any widely-used operating system.
I hear &winlink; is pretty nifty when it works, but I'm mostly uninformed about it.
